moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 e6 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e3 h6 5: First aggressive move. If f6, Qh5+.
moves.7... b5 8. a3: Normal. Black can cause problems on the Qside.
moves.10... Ne4 11. Ndf3: This supports the center after f6, Nd3.
moves.11... Bxe5 12. dxe5: This cramps both of us, but I think it is better that a lot of exchanges and loss of tension.
moves.13. gxf5: Better than exf6 ep. ? I'm not sure. My plan was to make a hole in d6 for my pawn.
moves.13... exf5 14. Nd4: He can exchange my N, and my e6 plan will be delayed. But I'll have a wonderful pawn chain, so I won't complain.
moves.14... O-O: ? Very bad, just in front of the open column.
moves.15... Nxd4: You see, the idea is that if I take the N with the Q, Bxe6 and d5 is defended. BUT...
moves.16. exd7: Black has to retire the N, and now d5 IS not defended, and my Q will take it with check! Any other move loses a piece.
moves.16... Qxd7: ? Black preferred to lose the N. If Ne6, Qxd5. Qe7 and it seems holdable.
moves.19... c5: Too late, since I take with check. c6 would have been wiser. Qb6, though...
moves.20. Bxd5+ Nxd5 21. Qxd5+ Qxd5 22. Rxd5 c: If Rd7, Rf7 and nothing special happens.
moves.26. Rd6d7: Winning, but how, exactly? I've seen the mate position here.
moves.28... Rae8: Simply Bxg7 wins, but I wanted a mate.
moves.29. Bf4 Ref8: Black can do nothing but wait.
moves.30... Rfd8 31. Rxh6#: I'm sure she was shoked. It happens sometimes.
